Issues.Title: Cannot use `attr.disabled` and `ngModel` together to disable fields [ng15]
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Starting in Angular 15, an input field will not be disabled when using  `[attr.disabled]="true" [(ngModel)]="someValue"` when first rendered

We're [using this feature](https://github.com/vmware/vmware-cloud-director-ui-components/blob/master/projects/components/src/form/number-with-unit-input/number-with-unit-form-input.component.html#L17-L26) and caught this while updating https://github.com/vmware/vmware-cloud-director-ui-components to ng 15 from [one of our unit tests](https://github.com/vmware/vmware-cloud-director-ui-components/blob/master/projects/components/src/form/number-with-unit-input/number-with-unit-form-input.component.spec.ts#L311-L318). Initially, I naively used `[disabled]="shouldBeDisabled"` and it fixed this case but broke[ a bunch of other cases](https://github.com/vmware/vmware-cloud-director-ui-components/blob/master/projects/components/src/form/number-with-unit-input/number-with-unit-form-input.component.spec.ts#L320-L325).



It works in [Angular 14](https://stackblitz.com/edit/ng-14-attr-disabled-ngmodel?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts,src%2Fmain.ts) but does not work in [Angular 15](https://stackblitz.com/edit/ng-15-attr-disabled-ngmodel?file=src%2Fmain.ts)


The following code will not disable the text input


```
@Component({
  selector: 'app-root',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [CommonModule, FormsModule],
  template: `<input [attr.disabled]="true"  [(ngModel)]="myName" /> `,
})
export class AppComponent {
  myName = 'Angular';
}
```

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/ng-15-attr-disabled-ngmodel?file=src%2Fmain.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
The input field does not become disabled. If I toggle its disabledness after rendering, it will work.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Replicated in a simple stackblitz ng 15 starter. Proved that it worked in an ng 14 version.
```

```
[@angular/animations](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/animations)
15.1.0-next.2

[@angular/common](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/common)
15.1.0-next.2

[@angular/compiler](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/compiler)
15.1.0-next.2

[@angular/core](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/core)
15.1.0-next.2

[@angular/forms](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/forms)
15.1.0-next.2

[@angular/platform-browser](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/platform-browser)
15.1.0-next.2

[@angular/platform-browser-dynamic](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/platform-browser-dynamic)
15.1.0-next.2
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler): rework and expose APIs to be used in schematics
Issues.Body:
Reworks some of the existing compiler APIs to make them easier to use in a schematic and exposes a few new ones to surface information we already had. High-level list of changes:
* `getPotentialImportsFor` now requires a class reference, instead of a `PotentialDirective | PotentialPipe`.
* New `getNgModuleMetadata` method has been added to the type checker.
* New `getPipeMetadata` method has been added to the type checker.
* New `getUsedDirectives` method has been added to the type checker.
* New `getUsedPipes` method has been added to the type checker.
* The `decorator` property was exposed on the `TypeCheckableDirectiveMeta`. The property was already present at runtime, but it wasn't specified on the interface.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(compiler): rework and expose APIs to be used in schematics" (#48730)

Issues.Body:

Issues.Title: Named router outlet separator is a reserved character
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

router

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When using named router outlets, the secondary route consists of the outlet name, a colon separator and the path. [Taken from the Guide](https://angular.io/guide/router-tutorial-toh#secondary-route-navigation-merging-routes-during-navigation):

`http://…/crisis-center(popup:compose)`

My main problem is, that IIS will return a Bad Request (HTTP 400) when this route is directly navigated or refreshed as it is an invalid character. The Angular-App works perfectly if navigated on the client (via routerLink).

As far as I was able to find, the colon (":") is a reserved character in a URL [RFC 1738](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc1738) but seems to be permitted in query-params after the "?" (at least on IIS).

My suggestion is: Change the separator for named router outlet name and path **OR** make the separator at least configurable to something else.

I found [this resource](https://www.blinkingcaret.com/2018/04/12/iis-colon-url-angular/) to change the `UrlSanitizer` and will probably resort to this workaround but I think Angular should consider changing this.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
HTTP 400 - Bad Request
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 13.3.5
Node: 16.14.2
Package Manager: npm 8.5.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 13.3.6
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... google-maps, language-service, material, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server, router
... service-worker

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------

```

```

```

Issues.Title: NonNullable FormControl is assignable to Nullable FormControl, leading to deceptive type safety
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Use case: a component with an input of type `FormControl<boolean | null>`. User is able to assign a `FormControl<boolean>`. Component can internally set null as value. User receives an unexpected value at runtime but no compiler error.

```
const nonNullable = new FormControl(false, {nonNullable: true});
const nullable: FormControl<boolean | null> = nonNullable;
nullable.setValue(null); // nonNullable control receives value null which it does not expect;
```

Per default typescript does not handle variance / restrict variance. TypeScript 4.7 introduced [variance annotations](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-4-7/#optional-variance-annotations-for-type-parameters). Marking TValue in FormControl as invariant solves the problem in my reproduction test. But I don't know all the effects this change would have applied in Angular.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-ntzwtb?file=src/app/app.component.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
The error is: no compile time error for assigning the nonNullable control.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 14.2.2
Node: 18.13.0 (Unsupported)
Package Manager: npm 9.1.2
OS: win32 x64
```

Issues.Title: fix(core): makeEnvironmentProviders should accept EnvironmentProviders
Issues.Body:
`makeEnvironmentProviders` constructs the wrapped `EnvironmentProviders` type, which can only be used in environment injectors (not element injectors). It makes sense that `makeEnvironmentProviders` should be able to accept existing `EnvironmentProviders`-wrapped providers, since it will be providing the same guarantee, but the current types do not allow this.

This commit fixes the typings to allow nesting `EnvironmentProviders` and adds a test to verify that it will work.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(core): makeEnvironmentProviders should accept EnvironmentProviders" (#48720)

Issues.Title: Problem with inputs checked
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? core ### Is this a regression? Yes ### Description A problem occurs with inputs that are checked when they should not to be. The issue can be reproduced with a component that contains a list of values that must be applied when displayed. Component containing the list of elements and a method to update a state: ```typescript import { Component } from '@angular/core'; @Component({ selector: 'app', templateUrl: './app.component.html', styleUrls: ['./app.component.css'], }) export class AppComponent { public readonly elements: Array = [true, false, false, false]; public update(event: Event, index: number): void { let element: HTMLInputElement = event.target as HTMLInputElement; this.elements[index] = element.checked; } } ``` The associated template: ```html
#{{ i.toString().padStart(2, '0') }}
``` When the first item is unchecked by a click, the value is correctly set to `false`. But when the state of the first one will change again to `true`, the second element of the list will have its checkbox checked (its value is still set to `false` in the array). You can find below a [demo](https://stackblitz.com/edit/c5a938f8-e80d-4245-89b9-de05517abcb5) step by step. 1. Load the page. ![Screenshot 2023-01-12 at 16 30 13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7528452/212109635-8cead047-4699-4dfa-9a3e-706a49c66474.png) 2. Click to the first element. ![Screenshot 2023-01-12 at 16 30 24](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7528452/212109639-6cfb7261-32ce-46c8-9f2d-3abd74aa7a20.png) 3. Click to the first element. ![Screenshot 2023-01-12 at 16 30 29](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7528452/212109642-9e8ef87d-6c51-40c2-8cc2-0327906b34ca.png) If you continue to click on the first element, the third element will be modified, then the fourth, etc. ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug https://stackblitz.com/edit/c5a938f8-e80d-4245-89b9-de05517abcb5 ### Please provide the exception or error you saw _No response_ ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular CLI: 15.0.5 Node: 18.12.1 Package Manager: npm 8.19.2 OS: darwin arm64 Angular: 15.1.0 ... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router Package Version --------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.1501.0 @angular-devkit/build-angular 15.1.0 @angular-devkit/core 15.1.0 @angular-devkit/schematics 15.0.5 @angular/cli 15.0.5 @schematics/angular 15.0.5 rxjs 7.5.7 typescript 4.8.4 ``` ### Anything else? Issues.Title: Caching in service worker isn't working when path is generalized.
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

service-worker

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

 When I'm configuring my dataGroups for caching in ngsw-config.json, if I specify the full path, only then the caching works. Otherwise, It doesn't cache.

This works:
"dataGroups": [{
      "name": "getRequestCache",
      "urls": [
        "myapp/ai_models",
        "myapp/ai_models/parameters"
      ],
      "cacheConfig": {
        "strategy": "freshness",
        "maxSize": 1000,
        "maxAge": "3d",
        "timeout": "10s"
      }
    }
]

This doesn't work:
"dataGroups": [{
      "name": "getRequestCache",
      "urls": [
        "/**",
       "/**/**", 
       "/**/**/**"  
       ],
      "cacheConfig": {
        "strategy": "freshness",
        "maxSize": 1000,
        "maxAge": "3d",
        "timeout": "10s"
      }
    }
]

Is there any way to not write each path specifically and assign a general path, so that everything gets cached?

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

Issues.Title: feat(router): helper functions to convert class guards to functional
Issues.Body:
This commit introduces helper functions to easily convert `Injectable`s with functions compatible with `Route` guards to the corresponding guard functions. These functions will serve to aid in migrating off of the now deprecated class-based guards, but also provide an easy avenue to still defining guards as `Injectable` classes if that is desired.

Reviewer notes: Open to bikeshedding the API here. We could just have separate functions for each type of guard. I thought grouping them would help in discovery but maybe it's more confusing than the alternative.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(router): helper functions to convert class guards to functional" (#48709)

Issues.Title: Revert "test: use `NPM_CONFIG_legacy_peer_deps` when testing prerelease versions of Angular material."
Issues.Body:
This reverts commit 04e7c25aad3644d0502f0ae30308ccabf4db43ea as it is no longer needed due to the recent changes done in the material packages to expand the peer dependency.
See: https://github.com/angular/components/commit/6afe888a1a1c840c371991051335c19b6a1bdf95
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Revert "test: use `NPM_CONFIG_legacy_peer_deps` when testing prerelease versions of Angular material."" (#24548)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): prevent hanging initial build during exception with esbuild
Issues.Body: When using the experimental esbuild-based browser application builder and an exception is thrown during the initial build, the process may hang indefinitely due to the Sass worker pool not shutting down fully. This does not happen for rebuilds after the initial.  To remedy this situation, The initial build is now wrapped in a try block to ensure that a full shutdown of the Sass worker pool occurs.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): prevent hanging initial build during exception with esbuild" (#24549)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): register schematic aliases when providing collection name in `ng generate`
Issues.Body:
Previously, schematic aliases were not registered when a collection name was provided to `ng generate`.  Example: `ng generate c` where `c` is an alias for `component` would work, but `ng generate @schematics/angular:c` would fail. This commits fixes the schematic registration to handle the latter case.

Closes #24518
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular/cli): register schematic aliases when providing collection name in `ng generate`" (#24542)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support CommonJS dependency checking in esbuild
Issues.Body:
When using the experimental esbuild-based browser application builder, input files
for the build will now be checked to determine if they are non-ESM modules. This
behavior is comparable to the existing behavior within the default Webpack-based browser.
Warnings will now be issued for any non-ESM modules (for example, CommonJS or UMD) when
script optimizations are enabled (typically production builds). ESM files can be tree-
shaken and otherwise optimized in ways that CommonJS files cannot which allows for
more optimized and smaller output bundle files.
If any allowed dependencies are provided via the `allowedCommonJsDependencies`
option, both the direct import and any deep imports of the dependency will be ignored
during the checks and no diagnostic will be generated for the dependency.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support CommonJS dependency checking in esbuild" (#24522)

Issues.Title: [@angular-devkit/build-angular@12.x] digital envelope routines::unsupported
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

I know that **Angular v12** are no longer under support but `@angular-devkit/build-angular@12.2.18` should support `node: "^12.14.1 || >=14.0.0"` and is actually breaking in `node 18`...

### Issue

After upgrading to **Node.js 18**, I'm getting the following issue during the build process of an ng12 project:
```sh
...
Compiling @angular/forms : es2015 as esm2015
node:internal/crypto/hash:71
  this[kHandle] = new _Hash(algorithm, xofLen);

Error: error:0308010C:digital envelope routines::unsupported
    at new Hash (node:internal/crypto/hash:71:19)
    at Object.createHash (node:crypto:133:10)
    at BulkUpdateDecorator.hashFactory (/home/runner/work/demo-app/node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/node_modules/webpack/lib/util/createHash.js:145:18)
```

According to this [stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/69692842/error-message-error0308010cdigital-envelope-routinesunsupported/73465262#73465262), this is due to:
> Node uses OpenSSL for its hash functions and encryption on *nix systems. The latest version of OpenSSL disables MD4 by default—which will break any previously working program that uses MD4.

### Fix
As we can see from the log, the issue comes from `webpack`.
They fixed it in [v5.61.0](https://github.com/webpack/webpack/releases/tag/v5.61.0) by using a wasm md4 implementation for node 17 support.

But issue also occurred with `babel-loader` that got fixed in [v9.0.0](https://github.com/babel/babel-loader/releases/tag/v9.0.0) by updating their hash method from `md4` to `sha256`.

So the fix here, would be upgrading **webpack** and **babel-loader** dependencies of **@angular-devkit/build-angular**.

_(as a test, I've tried manually upgrading them in my `package-lock.json` and this solved the issue)_


### Minimal Reproduction

-

### Exception or Error

```text

Compiling @angular/core : es2015 as esm2015
Compiling @angular/common : es2015 as esm2015
Compiling @angular/platform-browser : es2015 as esm2015
Compiling @angular/platform-browser-dynamic : es2015 as esm2015
Compiling @angular/router : es2015 as esm2015
Compiling @angular/common/http : es2015 as esm2015
Compiling @angular/forms : es2015 as esm2015
node:internal/crypto/hash:71
  this[kHandle] = new _Hash(algorithm, xofLen);
                  ^

Error: error:0308010C:digital envelope routines::unsupported
    at new Hash (node:internal/crypto/hash:71:19)
    at Object.createHash (node:crypto:133:10)
    at BulkUpdateDecorator.hashFactory (/home/runner/work/demo-app/node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/node_modules/webpack/lib/util/createHash.js:145:18)
    at BulkUpdateDecorator.update (/home/runner/work/demo-app/node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/node_modules/webpack/lib/util/createHash.js:46:50)
    at RawSource.updateHash (/home/runner/work/demo-app/node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/node_modules/webpack-sources/lib/RawSource.js:77:8)
```

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/core): handle number like strings in workspace writer
Issues.Body:
The workspace writer previously transformed number like strings to numbers which causes failures when a project is named using a number like name.

Closes #24541
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/core): handle number like strings in workspace writer" (#24543)

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): remove direct import of i18n worker code
Issues.Body:
The i18n inlining worker code was previously imported in several locations to allow reuse of the options object used to configure the worker. To prevent the worker code from being used outside of an actual worker, the options object definition is now located in a separate file and imported in both the worker and any other files that need to use the inlining options.
The unused worker bootstrap file was also removed since it was only need with the legacy unit testing setup which has been completely replaced.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): remove direct import of i18n worker code" (#24539)

13

Issues.Title: SCSS not compiled correctly -> no error/warning on console
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [x] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Provided a repo to test it with angular 15.1.

https://github.com/meriturva/ng-scss-import-issue

Simply style on `body` (after all imports on file `style.scss`) is not produced without any error.
(see https://github.com/meriturva/ng-scss-import-issue/blob/main/src/styles.scss#L28 )

Just try to comment one of import on file `style.scss` `body` style start to be compiled/produced correctly.

I guess it is something related to memory but no error is logged on console.
Executing `ng serve --verbose` produces quite different logs:

When issue is present: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/meriturva/ng-scss-import-issue/main/log-when-issue-present.log
When issue is NOT present: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/meriturva/ng-scss-import-issue/main/log-when-issue-NOT-present.log



### Minimal Reproduction

To reproduce the issue just run `ng serve` on the repo provided and you will not see the page with a red background.

Commenting one of the imports on file `style.scss`  fix issue and page is now red.

Issues.Title: Memory leak during build process after updating to Angular 15
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.2.8

### Description

Hi,

After upgrading from Angular 14 to Angular 15, our library project has dramatically increased the amount of RAM needed to build the project. It never surpassed 8GB of RAM on build time with Angular 14, but after upgrading to Angular 15.1, it needs up to 25GB of RAM... it doesn't seem like a normal change. Furthermore, it takes far more time.

Issues.Title: bug(mdc-migration): Migrate components selectively is bugged
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When Migrating to MDC-based Angular Material Components, and doing it component by component, it should only migrate the selected components. Right now other components that are not selected are also migrated. Seems that it only happens on imports.

Take for example this ngModule code:

```typescript
      import {NgModule} from '@angular/core';
      import {MatLegacyButtonModule} from '@angular/material/legacy-button';
      import {MatLegacyCheckboxModule} from '@angular/material/legacy-checkbox';

      @NgModule({imports: [MatLegacyButtonModule, MatLegacyCheckboxModule]})
      export class AppModule {}
```

Right now, migrating this file selecting only the "button" migrates also the Checkbox. This should not happen. 

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:

Execute the migration for only "button" on this ngModule code:

```typescript
      import {NgModule} from '@angular/core';
      import {MatLegacyButtonModule} from '@angular/material/legacy-button';
      import {MatLegacyCheckboxModule} from '@angular/material/legacy-checkbox';

      @NgModule({imports: [MatLegacyButtonModule, MatLegacyCheckboxModule]})
      export class AppModule {}
```

### Expected Behavior

Should migrate only selected components

### Actual Behavior

Selectively migrating components is buggy and in some cases, like imports, other components are also migrated

### Environment

- Angular: 15.1.0
- CDK/Material: 15.1.0
- Browser(s): -
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Ubuntu
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mdc-migration): Migrate components selectively is bugged" (#26426)

Issues.Title: build: adjust peer dependency to include all minor pre-releases
Issues.Body:
Pre-release versions of Angular Material should be compatible with the same pre-release versions of FW (being worked on at the same time).

Additionally we want to expand the peer dependency so that the pre-release Material version is also compatible future pre-release of framework. e.g. consider the scenario where Angular framework already released `15.2.0-next.0`, while both CLI and COMP are still on `15.1.0-next.0`.

CLI in this case want to depend on the latest
versions, but with the recent stricter NPM version this would break as Material wouldn't allow `v15.2.0-next.0`

We switch to a more simpler model that requires less changes by the caretaker. For `@next` releases we will be more flexible and allow for all pre-releases of the current major and (N+1)-next/rc

Also we no longer require the peer dep to be updated manually.

This simplifies the caretaker experience as the peer dependency would no longer need to be updated manually every time the release version changes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: adjust peer dependency to include all minor pre-releases" (#26421)

Issues.Title: Mat Chip Test Harness: Support editing chips using the test harness
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

`matChipInputFor` allows editing input values after a chip has been created (e.g. https://material.angular.io/components/chips/examples#chips-input), however, none of the relevant test harnesses support performing an edit action (e.g. https://material.angular.io/components/chips/api#MatChipRowHarness). There appears to be a `isEditing()` method, but no apparent way to use the test harness to get the chip row into an editing state (and no way to actually perform the edit even if you do manage to start editing via `const host = await chipRow.host(); await host.sendKeys(TestKey.ENTER)`).

### Use Case

Editing chips is finicky and non-trivial to simulate in test code. Without this feature, components that support chip input editing either have to:
- Not test their editing functionality OR
- Use brittle and unreliable methods of triggering and performing the edit e.g. directly accessing the matChipInput instance or the editable span.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Mat Chip Test Harness: Support editing chips using the test harness" (#26419)

Issues.Title: bug(menu): type MenuCloseReason not exported in public api
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The type [MenuCloseReason](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/material/menu/menu.ts#L55) is not exposed through [public api](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/material/menu/public-api.ts#L9).

It's been around for quite some time now, so I guess it's pretty stable. Why not make it part of the public api, pretty please?

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. create a component that contains a `<mat-menu>`
2. listen to the `(closed)` event
3. use the event type (`MenuClosedReason`) in the event handler function

```
import { MenuCloseReason } from '@angular/material/menu';

@NgModule({
  template: `<mat-module (closed)="onMenuClose($event)"></mat-menu>`
})
export class TestComponent {
  onMenuClose(event: MenuCloseReason): void {
  }
}
```


### Expected Behavior

[public api](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/material/menu/public-api.ts#L9) of mat-menu should export `MenuCloseReason`.

### Actual Behavior

[public api](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/material/menu/public-api.ts#L9) of mat-menu does not export `MenuCloseReason`.

### Environment

- Angular: 13.x, 14.x, 15.x
- CDK/Material: 13.x, 14.x, 15.x
- Browser(s): n/a
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(menu): type MenuCloseReason not exported in public api" (#26416)
